39359529.review: I don't know how to describe how much I love this game other than I really, really love it.  I'm quite the big fan of visual novels and this one has instantly jumped to the top of my reconmendations and favorites list.  The writing is so charming and funny (and relatable), the art work is very unique and beautiful, the story is very solid and endearing, and every character route is fun, warm, and actually has a conflict that helps Avery grow closer to their love interest.  I have played so many games where conflicts were ignored or skipped over without meaningful resolutions, but Hustle Cat nails them perfectly and it helps make the game so much more lovable and engaging, at the end I cared about every character, even the one that didn't grab me at first.  As much as I wish there was more to see with these characters, I actually like the fact it's fairly short for a VN -- it is very short and sweet and I know I can go replay any route I want to whenever I want to without making a massive time commitment.  Two other amazing things: the sountrack and Avery.  The soundtrack is really, really good and I've been listening to it for months now (I'm listening to it right now).  Avery is mildly customizable in appearance and a choice of She, He, or They pronouns and this was just amazing to me; I didn't really think much of it at first besides it being cool, but at the end of my first route when Avery was refered to as "They," I almost cried.  It's something so small but it means so much.

39123363.review:
If you're not already convinced by the fact that the playable character works in a Cat Cafe, I don't know what will convince you.

Regardless, Hustle Cat has very quickly reached the top of my favourite Visual Novels list, and for good reason. The strongest point of this game is it's quirky cast. Avery themselves alone is an enjoyable character to watch fumble around. The various love interests will surprise you, and unlike most VNs, I don't think I actually found that I disliked a single route. I had favourites, naturally, but no route I disliked.

Going points for the game:
-You can play as male, female, or nonbinary. Your pronouns don't even have to match with your avatar!
-Be as gay or as straight as you want.
-Incredibly likeable characters.
-Great Soundtrack.
-CAT CAFE.

Points that you may or may not like:
-Main character is not renamable.
-Routes don't have bad endings. Instead, you'll only achieve a "bad ending" if you delibertly make a choice that hurtles you towards the bad ending. It's usually fairly obvious, and if even if you get this ending by accident, you'll get an achievement for it. Not to mention the game comes with an autosave option, so you can just reload the autosave afterwards.
-Even when you chose the male or the female avatar, the main character is still relatively ambiguous. Personally, I like this, but some people seem to dislike playing a female character that is not obviously female.
-Copious amounts of cats

Possible flaws:
-I couldn't help but feel like some characters of cast were easier to get than others. Which I suppose make sense, but sometimes I had to go out of my way to make bad choices for every member of cast except the love interest I was aiming for, and as a result I feel like Avery in that run didn't cultivate a strong relationship with their co-workers.
-Some people may not enjoy that the protagonist is a total slob.
-The begining of the game can get really repetative really fast. The "skip" feature is a little lacking, as it doesn't speed up any of the camera panning, and sometimes it just randomly stops altogether.


In conclusion, this may not necessarily be everyboy's cup of tea, but I do heavily reccomend it.
(Also I'm not entirely sure why it's marked as a "horror". It has some tense moments, sure, but that's just it's story, and to be honest once you've played through it once, those moments hold no tension at all. I wouldn't call it scary at all, and I'm pretty squeamish as it is)

Everything is cute, there's cats and coffee, and the story is heartfelt. Bonus points for being given the choice between multiple genders to date and letting the player choose their own pronouns--he/him, she/her, and they/them. 10/10 A+ <3 <3 <3

Graves, y'all. [i]Graves.[/i]

39072197.review:
I gotta say, I bought this during the Steam Winter Sale mostly because I was intrigued by the "horror" and "psychological horror" tags people assigned this (also couldn't say no to the sale). But I'm glad that got me to play this because man, this is a good one.

Pros:
-Intriguing story (the reason for the horror tags; nothing outright scary, though, so it's playable for even anxious people like me :3)
-Memorable characters (I loved spending time with these guys and even my least favorite date option--just out of all of them, I mean--still had a good route)
-Music that just won't get out of your head (Graves' theme seems to have stuck with me the most for some reason)
-Freedom to choose your gender (I like that you aren't stuck as a "guy only" or "girl only" character and can change Avery's gender to suit your preference... even in the middle of the game if you want. Far as I can tell, it doesn't seem to affect the story aside from pronouns as the characters seem to all be bi/pansexual anyway... or "Averysexual" if you'd rather use that term :3c)

Cons:
-Occasional glitches/bugs (I've had the game freeze up on me once; be sure to save and save often! That and the gallery stops letting you click on images after you view a few of them)
-Have to take screenshots the old-fashioned way: printscreen and Paint (if Steam screenshots would've been worked in, that would've been fantastic... but that's a nitpick)
-Would've liked more save slots (you get eight, but this is just me being nitpicky again)

Overall, I definitely recommend this game. You're in for a magical time--and cats!--while you [i]whisker[/i] (or 'im, lol) off her/his feet :3

38962101.review:
Okay. So, I love dating sims - but I'm pretty sensitive about mature content in games. I'm in it for the story more than anything else. That's why I'm happy to have found Hustle Cat.

The game itself actually isn't very long - you can easily finish each character route in about two hours or less - but you get plenty of enjoyment out of it. I also really appreciate that the game gives you the option to pick your appearance and gender right at the start, so you can play as either a boy or a girl (there is also a non-binary option). 

I quickly found myself becoming attached to every single one of the characters, even the ones I didn't like at first. Everyone is given a pretty interesting - and sometimes kind of depressing - backstory that makes you really end up empathizing with them. (For example, Reese, who I initially disliked, ended up being my favorite character after I played his route.) As for the romance and mature content, there's nothing in the game that would get a YouTube video flagged, if you know what I mean. There's some kissing (Reese and Hayes have some rather adorable blushing scenes) and a bit of language, but that's it, really. Just a lot of tender moments.

Oh, and did I mention that this game has some pretty decent music? Most of the tunes are actually pretty catchy. The piano/love theme was just downright beautiful, and has even made me consider buying the soundtrack.

The only thing I disliked about the game was that even once you've finished all the routes, including the secret one, you're still left with questions about the story. I'm not sure if the developers intended to leave loose ends or if they're planning on releasing more content, [spoiler]I REALLY would have liked to find out the reason behind Graves being cursed by Nacht and what the details were with their past relationship[/spoiler] but I just hate being left hanging!!

All in all, if you're looking for a somewhat lighthearted dating sim with a little bit of mystery - and not to mention cats - then you'll probably enjoy this wonderful charmer of a game.

Also, huuuge kudos to the developer for letting you choose your pronouns!! Loved that!! Anyways Hustle Cat is really good and I'd die for all of the characters and its just. Super good. You should totally play it.

38947543.review:
This game is cute, the art is sort of a sketchy watercolor style and the character style, while unique, grew on me after awhile. The length is about 9 hours I would say to do every route (I left mine running accidentally on the main menu for about 4 or 5 hours and that's why my time is higher). There is a lot of repetitive dialogue but there is a fast forward feature so that helps out. You can also save multiple files and at any point - there are two auto save slots as well, though there aren't that many decisions that you would need to save for. Routes get locked in fairly early and once you are locked into a route, I don't remember there being any other choices. Once your romantic interest is locked in, the story sort of just plays out from there. 

The story itself is a pretty straightforward set up - you're working your first job at a cat cafe with cute coworkers (both male and female romantic options, as well as you can decide what pronouns your character goes by). There's witchcraft involved and the same basic beats are hit in each route. But what I really enjoyed about this game was the writing - it's very modern, with very distinct character tones throughout. This is definitely not the normal stiff otome writing which I quite enjoyed. Your character has a very set personality, for better or worse. Personally I liked it but I could see that it would annoy some people.

The low points - the game is repetitive and maybe a bit short, the music wasn't that great (I never used headphones), nothing is voiced. But the high points - the writing, the stylization, the characters, I think out weight the bad and I definitely enjoyed this game.

38937333.review:
I was sent this game as a christmas present by a friend.

I like playing these visual novels (though mostly on mobile apps) and was looking forward to playing this one, but its not the best out there.

Like all these VN that let your pick a route I didn't feel that there were enough choices, the ones that were there became repected down every character route you take.

Another issue was that I was really looking forward to playing as a cat, but that route was never an option. If you run away from the cafe the games ends with you being stuck as a cat forever because you never go back. Err, sorry, but if I was suddenly a cat and the only way of being human was to be at the cafe and break my curse I would do that before storming out. How dumb.

Considering that the all the character routes were reparted it would have been a way to mix things up a little, maybe on the Hayes route, he prefers being a cat and it would have been esier to get to know him if you were both the same, and as the magic book is discovered at work it wouldn't be a problem for them to study it together at the cafe.

It was also very unsatisfactory to discover that the MC broke the cat curse before it took hold simply because you started playing with a stolen magic book and began teaching yourself spells; your don't even get some challanges to help your discover your magic or a choice of what that magic should be. Its just trash because the MC is a disgusting pig who can't pick up after herself and clean her apartment.

A plus point is that all the characters are different and have distinct personalities and problems, but the varity of the routes is ruined by the the script, which is lazy with each route having the same lay out; a date, a day at work, and the assult on the street by Nacht, and all of them using the same dialogues in placed between choices. Seriously, the fast forward button is just not fast enough in skipping through these sections. (Plus I discovered that using the fast forward button to frequently caused the game to crash.)

The images are inconsistant as well, in the Reese route the MC 'cleans' her place before letting her guest in, but the next morning the image goes back to the messy one, seems like the dev's picked the wrong image.

The endings were also the same with Nacht disposing of all the characters who you aren't dating while the MC does something stupid which results in your date coming to your rescue. Even timid little Hayes breaks character to come to your rescue. I realise this is all fiction but I found it hard to suspend my disbelieve here; the MC was supposed to have had the magic book, broken her curse, and been praticing for weeks yet is completely useless. While your date manages to break their curse and become a better witch in just a couple of days. We can forgive Landry and Reese to some extent because we discover that they are inheeritly magical anyway, but for the others it just doesn't work.

All of the endings are capped off with a little epilogue that doesn't explain why Nacht is after Graves, plenty of hints are given that it is not just about witches claiming new territory but you don't get a proper explaination. Not even at the end of the Graves route, when I expected all the answers and got nothing. You don't even get a proper epilogue with Graves about how they move their relationship on, you kiss after the fight with Nacht and the game ends. Where the devs are stretching bounderies with gay and non-binary options for the MC, it seems a relationship with a older guy was just too hard for them work with, so why bother offering it? Disappointing.

Time was also a problem for me of Graves's route, in all the other routes he is turned to rust instantly, but in his route he is able to resist the effects of it to come to the MC's rescue for over 24 hours. Yawn, backing tracking on five previous plotlines just to make his ending the same as the others makes no sense.

I loved the artwork and the concept, its just a pity that the devs didn't take some more time to write different cut scenes or offer more choices, after six routes all following the same patterns and choices the game ended up feeling repetative and samey. 

Less is more, as they say, and with more effort being placed into a smaller 'dating pool' this could have been more amusing than it was.

38892368.review:
I really love this game. 

I'm not a very big fan of VN dating games, but I like some of them, and this is one of the good ones.  
With a cute art style and some complex date-able characters, this game does a good job of mixing the two to create a nice, solid story with a ton of cats and a bonus hot goth guy. [spoiler]Who is also a cat. Sort of.[/spoiler]

Length-wise, it is relatively short with it taking me nine hours in total to complete every route (though I am a fast reader, and got bored skimming quickly over the parts I had already done to get to the romance options.)

You can be gay. You can be straight. You can be non-binary, male, or female. There are so very many options. 

My only quip is the lack of choices. Though the ones you make do affect your gameplay quite a bit, there are not so many as other games.

38883749.review:
The game is very fun, cute, and funny. It is also well written. In this game you can choose your character to be male/female/other by choosing the characters look of either more male or female as well as the pronouns you'd like to be called: he/him, she/her, and they/them. You can also choose between three skin tones. This is a really nice feature.

One thing I do dislike, is that the common route is 2/3 of the game, with the main romance part of each person's route is only about 1/3. The common route gets a bit boring/repetitive after two routes. Otherwise that's my main complaint for the game. A few others would be: the music sort of stops at times until you progress some more, saving the first time took awhile, two of the CGs are bugged, game could have been fleshed out a lot more, steam overlay does not work (so no screenshots), the protag also doesn't turn into a cat (not a big deal, but I was kind of disappointed that we didn't, would have been kind of cute), and a few others (but I kind of forgot at the moment.)

There are six love interests. Four males and two females. They are all unique and adorable. To unlock the sixth character, you have to complete the other five routes. Each route ends with the same thing [spoiler] fighting the rust witch, Nacht. [/spoiler] They are all done in their own unique ways, but are ultimately fairly similar.

This game did surprise me. I went into the game, not really expecting anything, just curious how it was going to play out the whole thing of dating people who ae also cats. I was thinking it would be something on the Hatoful Boyfriend level. It was not. It is a little more serious than that, though still has very humourous moments. There were also some side characters that I feel should have gotten fleshed out. Like the [spoiler] police woman who is friends with Finley, the witch the shows up in Landry's route, and the witch that shows up in Reese's route. [/spoiler] I really enjoyed those side characters, even though they were on screen for less than a minute each, some more depending how the story went. Granted those characters weren't the main focus, but they interested me. Same with the main antagonist. I kind of wanted more out of him [spoiler] and the way he was dealt with in the end. Like why the hell was he after Graves. None of that was explained or fleshed out. [/spoiler]

Overall, there could have been more. Might be nice to see some extra content in the future, but not sure if that would happen. I rec getting the game. It's a lot of fun and enjoyable and I got almost 13 hours out of it (would have been more, but I skipped the common route after the first two routes). Also sorry this review is all over the place. I may fix it one day.

38839735.review:
Completed once, as a female dating Finley.  Took 4 hours approx. Found it to be a short, but pretty enjoyable romantic visual novel.  Plenty of replay value for all the different endings (including at least 2 bad endings).

The story is fairly cute... it does have a lot of cats after all.  Although there are some serious elements, which I suspect change based on which character you date.  Finley's arc for example [spoiler] deals briefly with cyber bullying and stalking [/spoiler], and of course there is some body horror that the main story revolves around, which was unexpected, although fairly lightweight, and if you avoid the bad endings it all seems to end of a happy note.

Although on that body horror part, strangely the player character took it a lot better than I as the player did.  Guess they had to to keep the story on a cheerful note [spoiler] seriously, I think I would tried inflicting bodily harm on Greeves in an attempt to lift the curse as my instinctive reaction rather than just accepting it and getting on with the job as Avery did. [/spoiler]. But then again its not exactly going for serious grimdark.

Was a little disappointed that the various dialogue options largley end at the half way point, once your love interest has established.  After this its pretty much a straight visual novel playing itself out, but I enjoyed where the story went and it based itself around my relationship with said love interest, so can't complain.

Also, the ending for my once through left some big plot holes, specifically [spoiler] the reason behind the curse was never explained, although I can guess its the price of becoming an apprentice witch, but only Reese read the small print and knew to ask Greeves for magic lessons. Avery was self taught, but only because Greeves gave her the cipher[/spoiler].  But as there is a secret ending after you complete it with everyone else, I'm assuming all will be revealed then, and so its one of those games where you need to play through several routes before everything falls into place.

Overall, I'm definitely going to replay this dating Mason.  And normally I wouldn't bother with dating male characters, but the game's trick of not revealing those plot holes in my until the secret end (I'm assuming) has cleverly forced my hand.  And yes, I want to know that plot hole.  So, yes, I will be playing this several more times, pleny of replace value.

I'd certainly recommend, and be interested to see what else the developer is working on.

All you have to do is let it skip through the parts you've already seen and you'll get face fulls of cuteness from the route you chose afterwards. (My personal favorite was Graves, but I am a little biased since the first time I saw him and heard his theme music I had instantly wanted him!) Ahem...You can't change your name or your clothes, but I found that being able to go after any gender was fun enough as it was and made up for all that. The story, for me at least, seems pretty worth the price if the game is on sale. $20.00 dollars is probably a little too high of a price,(unless you compare to other dating games that are like $30.00+ for less content/satisfaction, then this is a great price x'D!), but since I usually don't have too much cash, the $5.00 sale was what I could work with. In short, I love the game, love the characters, LOVEEE the gallery photos, and love that it's involved in a cat cafe!!! Would fully recommend this game to anyone who loves a fresh romance!
P.S. I love that the main character has so much garbage in their life. (You'll know what I mean if you play the game LOL.)

First off, this game is a marvelous game. Not only do they give you a choice of the character's appearence, but also the pronouns Avery will go by. And it's a game you have to take your time on. Another thing I find facinating about the game is how no matter if you're romancing a female or male, the romnace is never questioned by either partner. The music is suberb and the art is great.

 Each route seems special and unique in their own ways, making each character their own instead of another route to complete. Their characteristics and personality are fleshed out throughly. However, one thing for sure that it it a bit confusing is how to get on the right routes for the person you are pursuing. [spoiler] You won't know until you reach the basement and unless you put a save file at the beginning, you have to start over for each route [/spoiler]At least you get to romance your [strike] hot [/strike] boss.

However, it does fall flat on functioning properly. The fast text option is very fickle and the achievements are a struggle when the game has a few bugs. 

Overall, the game is a good buy and an equally good story. The game is something I would recommend for people getting into VNs or people already into VNs. Just be wary of the bugs and other things that could affect your time with this game.

gosh this game is amazing. first of all, you don't have to be cishet; it's such a joy to be able to play a game that actually like, feels inclusive i guess? i'm pan + trans so big points there. it's also really cool to be able to pick your skin color!

37889755.review:
I know what you're thinking, "oh look another visual novel" but this one is surprisingly good. When I say good it's not heart rending or an epic story you'll be talking about for years. I mean it's good in that the writing is solid, characters are kind of endearing and it doesn't have some cringe worthy localization that raises eyebrows. You've got a short story featuring some cats and a cafe, two things that have been proven to work well together. 

The first playthrough will be your longest and you don't have to worry about any management elements in this game. It's very casual. There are a few choices you have to make to lead you to your romance option. There's no big boobs, nudity or sex but the story does lead to a tense climax and each path you play uncovers parts of the bigger picture. I enjoyed the other character's stories the most. Your own story is kind of non existent but that's forgivable in the grand scheme of this game. Other than that I think anyone looking for a casual light hearted story with should pick this up on sale.

37862115.review: If you like the otome genre, some sarcastic humor from protagnist very relatable to your high school/college years, and love cats, coffee and magic, this is the game for you. As you, Avery, start work at a cat cafe, with many options of people to "get to know", you start to realize there's more to this cat cafe then you first thought when you applied. It's a very heartwarming, sweet game where you learn about the characters and how they all ended up at the cafe and their backstory. Some are probably more "vanilla" than others, but that doens't make them any less enjoyable. I enjoyed the art style very much. I also enjoyed the fact that instead of one person dating people (where all the options are the same gender), you get a mix of both guys and gals to get to know and that's a little refreshing when it comes to dating sims that usually pick one gender (or in the case for Mystic Messanger, have one girl route that doesn't end the way you'd expect). I also liked where you can identify your own gender, which is a nice mechanic. Overall, very enjoyable game and highly recommend it.

On the plus side this game has nice artwork and they've illustrated a number of scenes instead of just reusing a half dozen.  The characters (including the protagonist) have their own personalities and there are player customization features that aren't common. 

On the negative side there is no fast foward through seen text option.  I was worried I'd miss new scenes while holding down spacebar to speed through since there's no back option, only a text log.  No real need to worry though because the first 2/3 of the game is the same and after that there are a few scenes that are essentially the same with window dressing that customizes them to the person you pursued.   It also crashes, but has an auto-save feature that helps make that less annoying.

If it has a compelling storyline instead of something average, and if romancing the characters actually seemed to make a difference in what happens I'd say buy it at full price.  However, as it is, I'd say wait for a deep sale. It would actually be a solid buy at 5 or 6 bucks.

Absolutely incredible, I fell in love with this game and it was just beautiful. You can't pick your own name unfortunately but in all honesty that was the only little bump I encountered with this game, the price is also a lot higher than I like it to be, but waiting for sales is never a bad thing! I will also say the writing is a bit short, but it kinda helps me out because I am extremely lazy when it comes to Otome games because they take FOREVER to get to the parts I want. So the short writing was good for me and helped me complete it without boredom.
Otherwise, it was just, dare I say perfect! I am a HUGE cat lover, and it was so lovely seeing a game like this, so the cat bit lured me in, but hell, when I started playing it I was amazed. First off, you are allowed to pick your own pronouns, including they/them, which just proves the game is extremely inclusive, there were also multiple skin colors to choose from when picking your certain look. That wasn't even the end though, not only were there routes for the guys but routes for the girls too. Of course, me being as gay as I am I went for Finley first, [who I absolutely adore haha], and I fell in love with her and her route. 
I was VERY impressed by this game, although it may not seem too long it is, and it is very story filled. Although I must say the waiting for romance was VERY difficult considering I got so attached so quickly, so I was obviously itching for something to happen. The characters are absolutely wonderful and you just end up falling for them in a heartbeat, the moment I saw and got to know them even slightly my heart melted with joy. I got so attached that when I completed Finley's route I was so sad! 

Overall, this game is DEFINITELY worth it. Especially if you're looking for an inclusive otome game that will give you major feelings and lots of happy moments. And if you love cats as much as I do. 
10/10 would recommend to anyone thinking about getting it. I was skeptical at first but I finally decided to get it and it was the best choice I made. You will absolutely adore this game and not want it to end!

37058901.review:
Hustle Cat is a very enjoyable VN with an interesting story and very likeable characters. I suck at writing proper reviews so here's some pros and cons:

Pros:
- You can choose the gender of your main character, or leave it ambiguous.
- There's love interests of both genders.
- The MC actually has a personality and actively takes part in the story, unlike so many other games where it feels like the MC just passively observes what's going on around them.
- All the characters are well written.
- The story is very entertaining and contains a lot of mystery, suspense and comedy.
- There's cats. Lots of cats.

Cons:
- It's a bit shorter than your average dating sim. I completed all routes in about 14 hours.
- Some of the relationships between the MC and their chosen love interest could've been fleshed out a little more.
- There's a few minor bugs in the game, but nothing that would impede gameplay.

I definitely recommend this game to any fans of the dating sim genre. And if you're new to these types of games it's definitely worth a try.

36901070.review:
A VN where the choices you make REALLY affect the outcome of the story.  There are many different routes to take, and the point of divergence for each path is relatively early in the story, resulting in the majority of each playthrough being entirely new content (assuming you have diverged along a different path than previous playthroughs).  The writing is very good and there weren't any glaring plot holes or spelling/grammar errors.  Be warned; some of the routes will really tug at your heartstrings.


Also, the 7.9 hours on record are 7.9 actual play hours.  No idling.  There is a massive volume of content here and it is well worth the price!

36869770.review:
This game is a gem. It might not look like much at first look, but it's everything an otome should be. 

First, a relatable main character. With an actual personnality. Bonus points : you can choose whether you want Avery to be a she, a he or a they - not something you see often in otomes (there are also a few customization options, including skin color). Second, the datable characters are all lovable and interesting in their own way, and you can date girls as well as boys. No yanderes, no push over, nothing cringy or borderline non-con like we usually get, if you want something cute and 100% consensual this is it. I played all the routes, expecting some of them to be downright annoying but even though I have my preferences I enjoyed them all. And third, the setting. You get to work in a cat café which is all kinds of amazing in itself, with the added bonus that all the employees can turn into cats themselves. I mean, sure, it's a bit of a stretch, but we've had people-turned-into-pets before (Dandelion) and stuff even less... likely (Hatoful Boyfriend, My Horse Prince) so really, nothing we haven't seen before. 

And it's funny. Like, really funny, with a lot of pop culture references because Avery is a nerd and I often found myself laughing at their lines. Some scenes even got me tearing up a little. The story is surprisingly compelling, the relationship with every character is sweet and cute and never feels forced or cheap, and the dialogues are delightful. I should add that there's a real story besides the romance aspect. And there's even a - very satisfying - secret route. Also, cats. The art is good, although I felt the CGs were a bit rushed sometimes? The gameplay is overall standard but that's really all we ask from a visual novel. I should warn that the game can be a bit buggy though. Took me time to unlock the secret route because my save files kept disappearing and I had to start all over again (thank god there's a skip option), which was really annoying. That's the only negative thing I can say about this game though. ...Did I mention there were cats?

 And with it being on sale right now, do yourself a favor, don't hesitate: grab it!

36855523.review:
The concept is fun, and there's plenty of waifus/husbandos to smooch if you run every route, though it suffers from each route being pretty short. As a result, the characters can feel a bit underdeveloped as you go from the point where the routes initially branch to the end of the game in barely 30 minutes, leaving them without much time to have proper character arcs. 
Likewise, the secret route kinda ends really abruptly. You get the smooch which is fab and all, but it could've definitely used some wrap-up afterwards or an epilogue like every other route had.

It's also surprisingly buggy for a VN. I had something like 4-5 CTDs during scene transitions, at one point the music completely cut out for 1/3rd of a run, and there was at least 1 or 2 grammar typos on each route.

The soundtrack was really nice tho. I'm a cheapskate, so you should buy it to compensate for me.

#MasonBestRoute

36157974.review:
Here's the teal deer:

BUY, BUT ON SALE

+ cute characters
+ nice artwork
+ fun premise
+ very LGBT+ friendly
+ funny & cute dialogue
+ likable protag with an actual personality
+ well-designed interface

+/- very railroaded once you've gotten into somebody's route

- weirdly-paced
- much shorter than you'd expect
- ?difficult to really get to know the characters
- generally left wanting More

Overall, I enjoyed my time with Hustle Cat, although I have a few criticisms. 

There wasn't as much player customisation as I usually like, but being able to choose pronouns (including they/them!), hair length, and skin tone were nice touches, and definitely better than being shoved into playing as a character you can't identify with like in some VNs. The game places basically no importance on your chosen gender, too - no homophobia or locked-out romance options here, folks!

The interface in general was really nice and very well-designed - a nice change from the same Ren'py layout every second VN uses! - although I would have appreciated a faster skip button and more than 8 save slots. (I'm a save-scummer, what can I say.)

The characters are generally cute and interesting, with witty dialogue and nice vibes. However, I didn't find myself getting as personally attached to them as I have to other VN characters - I'm not sure whether this is something to do with the writing or because of the short amount of time I got to spend with each of them. (The routes I played only took an hour or two each from start to finish, and less with skipping.) Their sprites (and Avery's!) are all well-done, with a decent variety of poses and facial expressions. 

Once you make a few choices about your first few days (who do you follow around? do you try to sneak a donut or not?) you're basically locked into a romance with one character and only have (I think) one more choice to make[spoiler], which barely even counts considering one of the two options leads to an instant game over[/spoiler]. Don't get me wrong, each route is cute in its own way, but I wouldn't have minded more personalization in your interactions with your crush, or even the ability to get a bad or neutral ending.  (Or even the ability to not romance anyone? I would have been really interested in friendship routes as well!) Also, there aren't many choices provided when you ARE given decisions to make, which makes it hard to really personalize Avery. (That being said, the writing is overall very good, they're a cute, funny, relatable protag, and I generally liked and agreed with them, so I wasn't too mad about this.) Depending on your priorities and what you like in a VN, this may or may not be a problem for you. 

As for the wider story - you really do have to play multiple routes to get a sense of what's going on, otherwise you're left with more questions than answers at the end. It's also paced a bit weirdly - there's a lot of time spent on introducing the cafe and the characters, some time spent at work slowly getting to know everyone, one or two cute dates [spoiler]and a magic scene[/spoiler] with your crush of choice where it feels like you just start to get to know them and then [spoiler]BAM, creepy magic guy shows up with no explanation, there's a very quick showdown, he's defeated and that's basically the end of the game. (It also seemed a bit weird to me that all the characters just kind of accepted that they'd been cursed to turn into cats - like, were they really not mad about being unable to be human outside one cafe? Do they not have outside friends or family who wonder why they never see them anymore? Neighbours? Landlords? It's not really addressed that well beyond "Graves is a nice guy and I guess it's our fault for not reading our employment contracts more closely", and while it didn't bother me so much in-game it's left me wondering once I finished.)[/spoiler] I also wanted to be able to spend more time with the characters and get them out of their shells more - even though you're dating and it's cute, you only effectively get a couple of days "together" before the game ends (and much of that is either skipped or just kinda brushed over), and it doesn't always feel like you the player got to know the characters very well. 

Overall, though, I enjoyed my time with Hustle Cat, and I'm really only critiquing it so heavily because I see a lot of potential in it. It was a fun, cute time for anyone who likes light urban fantasy and VNs. I definitely wouldn't pay $19.99 for it, though - try to get it on sale if you can. (I grabbed it in a Humble Bundle after having my eye on it for months.)

35773357.review:
I picked up this game randomly while searching through the visual novel category. When I looked up a summary about this, I thought it was quite interesting and decided to buy it during the deal. Since I love reading lots of visual novel, I said why the heck not. I decided to play on multiple of routes and after playing for a while, I saw some good things about it and also the bad ones. 

Some pros: 
+ I love the art style. It gives the overall game a relaxing theme in the game. 
+ The songs are catchy and fits well with the situation. 
+ Interesting character personalities. Even the main character her/himself is interesting. 

Some cons: 
- Music tends to stop here and there. I kind of understand what the creator was trying to do (such as building up tension and such in different situations), but at the same time, the music is suppose to be there to keep the reader from losing their attention from the game. Many games have music playing on repeat (even with environmental sounds in the background), so when there's nothing but soft, environmental sounds, it didn't feel right anymore. It might be different for some people, but for me, I did not enjoy it as much. 
- The plot was questionable. Not only did it felt rushed, but there were a lot of things that was left unsaid. It is fine to have some things left in question for the readers to figure out, but when there's nothing around the plot that can be easily theorized, it just left the players questioning what is going on overall. 
- The game crashes sometimes even while I'm playing or skimming through the routes. Sometimes, I get to the next scene (when the scene fades to black), and then I'm left there, waiting for more than a few minutes in darkness before it crashes the game. 
-Main character is "customizable" but not to an extent. I thought the layout of it was cool and interesting, but the way it was done was not that exciting. When I found out (after trying to click the box) that I could not change the name, I felt disappointed. Seeing a character profile sheet laid out almost made me think I can actually change the name, skills, and other things. I feel that it was better to have a different layout to choose a character instead. 


Overall, I did like the game, but not to an extent. It was a relaxing game, but it was almost stressful too when I see flaws here and there. I would recommend this game to you if you are not that picky with visual novel games, but overall, I wouldn't think of this as a part of my top choices.

35758490.review:
This is your standard VN/dating sim game. Nothing earthshattering here--in fact, this may be one of the weaker ones I've played as you really don't get to make too many choices in the game. You don't even get to develop a personality for your character; Avery Grey is predetermined. The only thing you can change is your pronouns, and your look to a minor extent. 

The story is quick. Like many romance games or novels it's TOO quick really; the plot advances so fast that there are gaping holes left when you've finished the story. But it's a cutesy story with an interesting twist (a twist that you may have gleaned just from reading the game blurbs or store page). It is absolutely nowhere near worth the $20 steam price however--I'd be furious to pay that kind of price for such amateur writing. If you're a completionist who wants to play every romance option in a VN, well, I can't give you any advice there as I can't imagine playing this a second time through. The pacing without options is too slow for me to even consider that. Expect an hour or two out of this game and call it good. 

You may also want to stock up on coffee and jelly doughnuts before playing this game. Just trust me on that one.

35700633.review:
VNs are, or maybe should be, ultimately about getting to know characters, and Hustle Cat gets this, avoiding the usual otaku-pleasing route of assembling the bunch of bare-bone, trite anime tropes, and presenting instead a likable, for the most part, cast of characters that, while somewhat archetypical, don't look like building blocks out of a set; the anime art-style is nice, but if you switched it out for a different one, the word "anime" would probably and hardly cross your mind.

The premise, in equal parts Faustian of sorts, Human Centipede, and Cats-and-the-Internet, is about a young'un, out of a job, with no money, and trying to find a way in the big city while living at their aunt's flat, who carelessly signs away their soul, or better yet, takes a job at a cat-themed cafe, involving a curse turning employee into cats whenever they leave the premises; it is one that if you had pitched to me, I would have replied "thanks but no thanks".

I found the writing enjoyable overall, if a bit lightweight, and it's definitely a plus that the gender identification of the main character is customizable, and all of the characters can be romanced, regardless. Also, no sex whatsoever.

The ending, however, feels somewhat simplistic, hurried perhaps?, and left me kind of disappointed, not very willing to go back and play a different story-line, as I imagined this would have been, for the most part, replaying the same story with just a different character being romanced. BTW I got in a same-sex relationship with Finley in my first playthrough, without trying: I was fine with it, although it felt a little sugary, lovey-dovey for my tastes.

I cannot remember the last time I was able to finish a VN, without succumbing to continuous attacks of eye-roll-itis, so this gets my thumbs up: while not without flaws, I would say the positives prevail, and Hustle Cat is a relaxing, enjoyable experience that doesn't go anywhere terribly interesting in particular, being content with entertaining the player with a tale of finding friendship and love.

35530293.review:
First off-I'm typically not a huge fan of dating sim/visual novel type games. Many tend to either pin you with basically no ways to change the plot and just present it like it's an actual novel, or have the protagonist do things to woo potential dates that don't fit with the protagonist's personality/are basically lying to get characters to like you. This game does neither, which is great to see. First off, the protagonist (Avery Grey) has a rather defined personality, and some very amusing dialogue. Secondly, while some of the stuff gets repetitive (they have a fast forward feature probably for that reason) the story is very engaging and how things play out does change with each path--at least in how the end is reached. The only two 'bad' paths are ones that are fairly easy to find and avoid (or do--they've got achievements for both and they're both worth looking at, even if you only do them the one time) and won't force you to totally restart the story or anything like that. 

All the characters are fun, interesting, and have more depth to them than many dating sim ones do--no completely shallow stereotypes here! Also, while Avery is set personality and dialogue wise, you can (somewhat) choose their appearance and you can choose their pronouns as well (she/her, he/him, OR they/them). Also you can date whoever you want, no matter what pronouns you went with, and to boot you can change the pronouns at any time from the main menu when you've started a game as well. 

Overall, if you like cats (and some other stuff) and dating cute coworkers while working in a... mysterious cat cafe, I'd absolutely recommend this game.

35448885.review:
[i]product bought in Humble Bundle for reduced price[/i]

All in all a pretty good visual novel. Not the best, but solid. The story is fairly strong, though after you've settled into a route it starts to railroad you pretty hard. Some of the options are pretty obviously the wrong one, and the really, absolutely vital relationship decisions are made for you. The choices you do make are more geared towards deciding what route you'll be going down. If you're a fast reader, you can finish a route in an hour.

The art is well done, and this is one of the few visual novels I've played where you have at least a small character creation section. While you can't rename your character, you can pick from six different appearances: 3 with longer hair that are slightly more feminine, and 3 with shorter hair that are slightly more masculine. You can also pick your character's pronouns, and switch them at any point during the game.

However, the differences in character appearance really boil down to hair length and skin colour. I understand it takes a lot of work to allow more customization, but it's important to mention that if you're looking for a visual novel where you have full control over appearance, this game won't be able to do that for you.

35442759.review: This game is adorable and it has a really calming vibe. Totally loved it.

35442054.review:
So a friend gifted this to me since he got it in a Humble Bumble and has no interest in VNs unlike me.
I went in with pretty much no expectations (saw the trailer, thought it's gonna be your classic run-of-the-mill dating sim) which is probably what really made this game amazing for me.
Just a note, this game crashes. Often. Try to save regularily, if you don't want to have to use the skip button eighteen times a run.

Story:
Unless one has played every route, both the main storyline as well as some of the characters behaviour and motivations is very obscure. Some routes reveal a bit about the others (Reese explains some about the main storyline, Landry about Mason, etc), but for a full picture one has to play all (and even then it leaves a few things open, sadly).
But the story was interesting and quirky and I especially loved the character progression in each route.
So the most important part is: this is NOT a cute, common dating sim!
Don't go in expecting to spend the entire run playing with cats and flirting with your guy/gal.
There are sceletons, dubstep, fire, rust (loads of rust actually, someone should clean that up xD), vampires? and possibly marine butterflies.
The game is weird and has a really obscure feel to it in it's humour. Let's just say I was giving a very, very simplified summary of a scene that got my attention in my friends group chat and they got so confused and intrigued that they now bought it as well (and they haven't regreted it to my knowledge yet).

Characters:
First of all, while the main character suffers from the occasional idiocy (let's run head first into a guy with a baseball bat, what could go wrong?!), they are relateable, cute and amusing to read along with (and I say "they" since you can chose the gender).
The other characters all come together in typical harem style: the cool type, the cute type, the shy one, the tsundere, etc. But nice is that all have a layer underneath (they're sweet or insecure or or or) which makes exploring their route fun, including learning a bit about who they are and how they ended up in the cafe. No one feels unecessary and the endings with everyone helping you is always quite heartwarming.
My personal favorites would be Mason and Hayes, but everyone is absolutely lovely and adorable during their respective route and I couldn't surpress grinning like an idiot whenever the inevitable started.

Art:
The art is solid, pretty much. Both the character and background drawings look a bit rough and smudgy, but it's charming and coherent, so it doesn't disturb in the least. And though the UI is flashy in colours, one soon stops noticing it. Plus, I really love title screens where you can see your progress.

Audio:
The game has a soundtrack of - what - six songs? It's a small game and music usually eats most of it, so people complaining about how repetetive it is obviously never made a small VN. The music at least never is annoying (I actually enjoyed listening to it, it's a bit cheesy but works with the mood most of the time and it could be way more jarring). The use of NO music is also used smartly whenever it happens, making you drop for a second every time.
There aren't any sounds of notice but that might be a good thing since certain games can become annoying with it.

Routes/Endings:
The game has six route endings and two Game Overs.
The first half of the routes is (almost) always identical and defines who you chose to be your darling, the second half then splits to the path of that character up until the end.
Be aware that this game is what I call a 2.5 kinetic novel. It has choices, but those only define who to date. Once you are in a route, you barely get a choice anymore and are only left with reading what happens. If you want to be able to meddle in everything, have a say to stuff and such, then this game will be very underwhelming (big props to the job interview though, I have never been this amused by choices).
It's also fairly easy to figure out when you're gonna get locked into a Game Over, but if you're into VNs as much as me, then you're probably wanna try and see them anyway.

Other:
While it would be a lie to say that this is the best VN I have ever played (there are some small typos and repeating words for example, there's also a bug where two CGs won't appear in the gallery despite having been seen in-game), it is definitely a lot of fun, quite interesting and very intriguing.
And hey, it has cats, dubstep and loads of lemonade (and Dracula), so you could hardly want more ;)

35357359.review:
I picked up this game randomly from a recent Humble Bundle, but I'm extremely glad I did. Hustle Cat is an adorable little visual novel that was also -surprisingly- extremely inclusive. You get to choose between playing as a female, male, or a nonbinary character (they/them pronouns), and both males and females are available as romantic options. If Date Nighto continues to make games of this caliber, I'll absolutely pick them up in the future. 

While I would put this in the 'pros' section below, I wanted to elaborate further on another aspect I enjoyed: the point system. Unlike most other visual novels I've experienced, you could probably complete each route successfully without relying on a guide. For the most part, no matter what choices you make, you do end up with someone (rather than getting a bad end and having to restart). I enjoyed being able to make my own choices in the game to see who I'd naturally end up with rather than worrying about having to start over. And if you are looking to get a certain route, it's pretty clear what choices make a certain person like you more. 

Pros (according to my own opinion):
-Inclusive
-Great art 
-Interesting storyline
-Graves and Reese
-Lots of cats
-Comedic moments intertwined with a more serious plot 
-Easy achievements
-Autosaving mechanic (especially useful when the game crashes)


Cons: 
-A bit short (I completed the game in approximately nine hours. I would enjoy more route-specific romance scenes.)
-Can't change character's name 
-Repetitive at times (Each character has their own story for character development, but the overall story resolves pretty similarly for everyone. I spent a lot of time skipping through dialogue.)
-Lots of sudden crashing
-Steam overlay doesn't work
-No trading cards

I liked this game a lot! You can choose your gender, skin color, so you can be a girl romancing a girl, guy romancing a guy, etc.  You play a rather androgynous character. Haven't seen that set-up in a dating sim before! The drawings are pretty decent, and holding down the space bar lets you move pretty quickly through dialogue that you've seen already. I managed to get every achievement in 7 hours - basically 1 day. Each route you take reveals another part of the story, so you really do have to play them all. 


My favorite routes were the shy poet barista (it's just really cute), the stoic bruiser cook (interesting backstory and great images), and of course, the hidden ending with your mysterious boss. The bratty assistant manager was also cute, I didn't know I'd be so into his tsundere-ness, but there you go. The most boring route for me was probably the famous social media girl. Just didn't have much personal investment in the relationship. Also liked the little hints that the game gave you. For example, there seem to be some romantic tensions between Gina the policewoman and the social media girl, and the tall handyman waiter and shy poet - if you don't romance them. I think the brat also has a crush on someone, but I haven't figured out who yet.

34848372.review:
As someone who loves cats, coffee and otome games, this was reccomended to me by a friend and I'm very glad I picked it up. Quirky, cuddly and witty, Hustle Cat is really worth the time for any otome fan and a great starting point for those curious about them. It's not perfect but it's a charming game for sure. 

The game is a joy to look at with a cartoonish art style and colourful palette. The soundtrack contains some catchy music - my personal highlight is the opening song, which I had in my head for several days. The characters are all likeable and there's a route for everyone here.  In all it took me about 10 to 11 hours to complete the game 100% and it was well worth the price I paid.

Highlights:
- Avery is a great protagonist. They have some very witty writing behind them and they ended up being my favourite character.
- The inclusion of allowing players to choose how Avery looks and their pronouns was such a welcome addition. 
- The story is short but intriguing, Each route offers something a little different and there's a bigger mystery to solve throughout them all. 
- This game can be hilarious. There's some very funny writing here which had me laughing a lot. 
- Good selection of romance routes that contain some nice character development and relatable moments.
- I'll mention it again but the art style is so good! The cats look adorable, the characters are all unique in design and the backgrounds  help to cleary set each scene.

Improvements:
The only thing I felt was that a few of the routes could of been a little longer. Some seemed to end rather abruptly after a point. Either a slightly longer epilogue for each route or a little more time before it gets to the climatic point would of helped flesh out the romances just that tad it needed.

Overall Hustle Cat is the type of game which is great to just chill out and take your time with. Its short length won't demand too much of your time and if you're looking for your romance fix without the 30+ hour investment of some bigger titles, you really should look no further. Its an enjoyable read with very cute cats and characters. Avery will continue to be one of my favourite protagonists in a visual novel for quite some time (I love their dry humour) and the setting is one I wish to re-visit on more replays. 

It's not without fault, but if you're looking for something sweet, filled with cats and a little magic, seriously give this a go.

33772104.review:
This was a beautiful game. Beautifully animated, beautifully structured, beautifullly everything. I can't find another way to describe it. The characters were incredible. Every single one of them had to offer to the game and not one of them was left out or cast aside. All of the routes were adorable and sweet and made you feel wonderful at the end. 

Something I really enjoyed tremendously, was the customization of the player's character and the elimnation of gender roles and labels in the game. The game treats love as just love, without having to characterize in some way. The player has the option to chose their labels as they please, without judgement or negative acknowlegment from the game or the interactive characters. You're treated as person, not as a gender. And that's something I really genuinely appreciate. 

The only issues I had were some giltches and the fact that some of my game play wasn't saved. When I first completed all the routes, everything seemed fine because on Steam, it acknowledged my achievements but not the game itself. Inorder to get to the secret route, I had to redo two of them even though I had already played them. It was as if Steam saved it, but the game didn't. So that might be something that should be checked out. Also sometimes the fastforward button would just stop working for no reason, and that was really bothersome. 

Overall, though, it was an incredible. 

Thank you, Date Nighto. I couldn't have asked for a better game. 
-Eli

33348153.review:
This review was written after completing every route and achievement in the game. I'd rate this game a 7.5/10. Although it is a wonderful game, there are some minor flaws that I hope will be improved in the future.

The first thing this game did right was to include three different pronouns, two different hairstyles and three different skin tones for the MC! There were also two female and four male love interests. Each character had different personalities and backstories, while the MC was both snarky and relatable. Art, although sometimes inconsistent, was beautiful.

However, the game was a little buggy and would often crash once in a while. I might be nitpicking here too - but the fast forward button was still pretty slow. Ctrl+Tab to access steam in game + F12 to screenshot do not work. Other than technical / programming errors, I felt that the story was very repetitive (at least for the first five love interests that you would be romancing). The overarching storyline is the same - for each of the five characters, you would experience the same common route and (almost) the same conflict and ending. Furthermore, after the common route ends and your love interest has been chosen, there is no further choices that you make. There is no bad ending.

This visual novel is also pretty short, which might make the drama, conflict and romance seemed a little rushed. Graves' story (I assume it is the true ending since it ties all the loose ends from the other routes together) - was different from the rest and made it a little less boring to read. My favourite routes were Graves and Reese.

Overall, I would recommend buying this game on sale - especially if you love light-hearted romance, nothing too serious... and cats! You can never have enough cats. Unfortunately, I don't think this game is worth buying at its full price.

[b][i]Hustle Cat[/i] is, quite easily, both one of my all-time favorite VN's and also just one of my favorite games, period.[/b]

33044745.review:
Hustle Cat is a game unique to the dating genre as you can date both human and cat, a feat attempted by not many developers.
I picked this game up recently during the Summer Sale and fell in love with it to the point where a friend and I basically finished the game in a day because we couldn't stop playing.

The game revolves around you, Avery Grey, and your new job at a cat café. Within your first few days, things get stranger and stranger, involving magic, cats, and all sorts of mayhem inbetween. The story, although not complex, is one that is best experienced by the player rather than read in a review, mostly due to its sweet and fun nature.

Pros:
- (limited but at least its still an option) character customization
- ability to pick your own pronouns
- can date any gender regardless of pronoun choices
- characters are unique
- writing is captivating and fun with very few grammatical errors
- the routes are well written when it comes to developing the main charcters/your dating choice
- art is very well done, bountiful cgs per route

Cons:
- game occassionally crashes, though the autosave feature will always have your back (in my 11 hours of playing the game crashed a total of 4 times)
- some of the story is kind of vague. even in the final route you don't get too much of a how or why things happen
- i lowkey wanted to date the bad guy but that wasnt an option

You wont really need too much of a guide for this one as the choices you can make have it be pretty obvious as to who you'll romance with what you'll say. I highly recommend this game for dating sim beginners, those who want to relax with a casual playstyle, or just want a generally cute but not extremely deep story (though it does have its moments).

Hustle Cat receives a 9.5/10 from me.

I personally love the game. The soundtracks for this game are very lush, relaxing, and beautiful. If you screw up or unsure about your decisions in the game, you have an option of saving and reloading your progress. The slight customization of your ambigous character and the option to choose your pronoun is a bonus. 32822594.review:
I was eyeing this title for a while and finally decided to get it during the Summer Sale. Zero regrets. It was a pleasant way to spend a day. It took me about 10 hours to reach 100% completion (consider that I used the fast forward button a lot during replays). Despite completing the game, I enjoyed it enough that I would consider replaying it later. It's definitely a decent addition to your library, especially on discount. I have paid more for far worse. 

As a plus point, you can pick from 6 player avatars of different skin tones, and also pick your own pronouns (he, she, they).  I don't know why more games don't do this. Best part is that you can switch the pronouns anytime during the game, so you can use whatever you're comfortable with to complement the character you end up dating ingame. It's a very nice detail.

Do note the game will sometimes crash. Save often! Sometimes it crashes when saving too.

[b]Story:[/b] I was expecting it to be a lighthearted game where cats turn into people and all you do is flirt to get their attention while drowning in catnip and inneundo. The story turned out to be more complex as you find out more about the cat curse. However, your options to deal with the curse are limited. Your focus remains on interacting with the other characters to decide whose route to land on. Each character is well-written and I loved each of their personalities. They felt realistic, and I would I love to know them in real life. I wish there would be a sequel or extra side stories. [spoiler]Maybe put the characters in an AU?[/spoiler]

There are a total of 6 routes, including the secret Graves route (unlocked after you complete all the other routes). There are several common scenes with very slight variations. Fortunately, there is a fast forward button to speed through them if you want. There is only 1 ending per character, and 2 common bad endings. On average, it took me 1.5 to 2 hours per route.

The story was original enough to get my attention. It has its cute moments and is peppered with humour. However, it could have used more depth. Only one route ([spoiler]Mason[/spoiler]) explored the difficulties they face from the curse e.g. [spoiler]Mason pretends she's a regular cat so she can spend time at the corner store. Aside from that, how long has everyone been cats? Doesn't anyone realise, especially Landry whose parents live in the city? And it would have been cool to see all their apartments or wherever else they hang out as cats outside work.[/spoiler] Ok, so maybe this isn't a priority since it's really all about Avery, but it would have made the story better.

I thought everything would be explained in Graves's route (common for secret routes), but his ending was rather abrupt. I was disappointed that they didn't fully explain about his past [spoiler]with Nacht[/spoiler], and about how this whole situation happened. I think a DLC prequel or sidestory would help close the loop.

[b]Music/Sound:[/b] There is no voice-acting, which is fine because the dialogue and characters' expressions manage to capture the tone. The opening theme song doesn't appeal to me but the rest of the music is on point. They even throw in some sound effects during the story. I like Graves's background music to the point that I'm thinking of getting the music DLC.

30924695.review:
Bought it when it was on sale. Would definitely recommend at sale price. Would probably recommend at full price. Basically if you've got the money to spend and are not bothered by anything you see. (if you want to know how long it takes: my total time is how long it took me to finish every route, get every CG & achievement, aaand I nodded off while it was running for almost an hour once.) Anyway. I love dating sims, and overall, I would say I had fun with this one. 

Pros: 
The storylines are cute, even the routes I liked the least had charming parts. Also I looove Reese's route it was so adorable. My heart melted. (Reese is 100% best boy pls date him.) 
Concept is interesting and unique as far as I know, (spoilersbutnotreally): all the characters are under a curse that turns them into cats when they leave the cafe. 
Said curse is broken by learning magic, and each character has a unique type of magic that they learn, develop, and then use to beat down the bad guy (well, Hayes and Finley's magic are a bit similar imo. But they're still all cool and impressive). 
The characters are pretty neat and most of them are easy to connect to emotionally. I even felt for Nacht a bit at the very end. 
Cats are consistently drawn very very cute.
You get to choose pronouns plus a character portrait. Cast is diverse! This is particularly exciting because it is not something you see very frequently in dating sims or VNs. 
Overall I'd say it has the makings of a pretty solid dating sim-type VN. And it feels like it was made with love!

Cons (I'm nitpicky, sorry. There's a lot here but I still enjoyed the game overall and would recommend. Well, unless there's anything here that's a dealbreaker for you.): 
Storylines are almost the exact same until about the halfway point no matter whose route you're on, which can get boring, especially because the skip option is rather slow and doesn't work if the window isn't at the front (for me, anyway).
Art for some characters looks a bit inconsistent between some of their portraits and CGs. And while probably most of the art looks pretty nice, some looks rather unfinished.
You can't change the character's name, and the differences between the feminine/masculine portraits for Avery aren't there a lot of the time (in almost all of the CGs the only difference at all is the hairstyle.) And the more feminine portrait's body type is basically just very skinny and slightly femme but mostly androgynous. If you like that, more power to you. But it's not super often I get to play as a girl who looks like me (see: brown) in a dating sim/VN so I wish I could've had a body that was more accurate too. 
Also, Avery in general I didn't find terribly likeable or relatable. Mason's route had me cringing at points (even though I found the reconciliation very touching), along with some of the Hayes interactions (I have very bad anxiety myself, and helping him do the dishes and that time where Avery says something about Hayes not liking them anymore as a joke and Hayes gives a startled/embarrassed just rubbed me the wrong way it felt insensitive lol).  
Last and definitely least important: I think the theme song is annoying.

30421430.review: This game is absolutely delightful. I've been wanting to get around to it ever since it was released, and tonight I finally sat down and spent some time with it. I didn't expect to immediately go through an entire romance route to the end of the game! The atmosphere, the music, the characters - everything just sucked me in until I had no bearing on how much time was passing in the real world. I immediately chose the Finley route (highly recommend, she's a cutie) and with games like this I'll usually only complete the routes of the characters I'm really interested in, and never touch the other ones. But with this game I know that I'm going to keep going through until I get every possible ending! It's so much fun and a lot of love was obviously put into it. The art style is adorable and I love the fact that you can choose your Avery's pronouns and skin tone, it makes the experience much more personal. Well-crafted, lovely game. 30403394.review: Lovely little VN. The characters are well written and don't come preloaded with wangsty backstories, they're all pretty normal for people who've ended up drifting into a cursed cafe full of cats. The character paths feel mostly uncontrived, and the second half of each path has a slightly different denouement to the main story's plot of magic that makes you want to play each one to get the full picture. Best of all, the main protagonist is not a blank slate or a milquetoast, he/she/they have their own character and powers, and is part of what drives the story forward rather than being dragged along for the ride. A tad expensive for the number of hours I got out of it, though as I bought it on sale, no regrets there.

30365548.review:
Overall, I enjoyed this game and had a good time completing it.

It hit the major things I like in life: cats, cute boys/girls, fun magic-y plot.

I would say all of the routes were good. Depending on your preferences, there may be a dud or two among the lineup. However, getting the full scope of backstories does enhance the game and its writing. Finishing just one or two routes would not be satisfying at all.

You do not get to choose your own name, and your customization options are limited. However, this allows for the art to be very nice quality. I thought the main character choices were cute and I was happy to be Avery. You do get to choose pronouns (he/him, she/her, they/them). I stuck mostly with the longer-haired he/him choice through my playthroughs if that matters. 

Going through each route can be tedious and repetitive, but that's what the skip button is there for. Unfortunately it is very formulaic in this way so your choices really only affect the last third of each story.

Your romance options are also cute and I wouldn't say there's a "bad" choice. I would say that the writing is strongest on the locked route, but it was my least favorite couple.

This was really a great length for me as I am not one to spend hundreds of hours on a game. I do echo previous reviewers in saying that length vs price ratio is a little off--but not insanely so. However, I did receive this as a gift during a recent sale which made it very worth it for me.

It's pretty obvious what you're getting into with this game, so I would definitely recommend picking it up if it piques your interest!

30309650.review: This game is absolutely fantastic, it's cute, interesting, has great music, the romances are just too precious and however designed and did the art for Landry did very~good work becuase that man is beautiful and I love everything about him

30306248.review:
This game wasn't really what I was expecting, but I'm glad I played it. The characters were fun and engaging, the art was nice, and the game is about magic & cats. I got the game on sale after reading the other reviews because I kept seeing comments about how it was so short- and they were right. I managed to tear through the game in about 5-6 hours (Steam says ~7 which includes times I left it up while I worked on other things). I admire the devs for trying something quirky and fun. I appreciate all of the work that clearly went into it, and the game definitely had me engaged. 


Pros:
- gender options (he/she/they) + avatar
- interesting characters
- cats
- magic stuff
- good dialogue / banter
- pretty easy to get through without messing up
- cute references / nerd culture
- fun story

Cons:
- lack of expansion (crushes suddenly developing / lots of unanswered backstory questions even after playing through all routes- ex. it seems even after the secret route the "big bad"'s motive is only hinted at and still uncelar)
- main character's unyielding behavior ( makes sense for base dialogue, but it feels like your choices have little meaning other than who you'll kiss. very little changes between choices sometimes even if you make the "right" choice- would have liked the choice to shape personality a little more than be given a linear progression)
- very short + the skip button only saves you a little time. (would be nice to skip right to the choices after already seen dialogue rather than waiting for the game to fast-forward)

**not a con, but it would have been nice to input a custom name & possibly chosen sexual preference


Overall, I think the pros outweigh the cons. I think if the devs had a little more funding/time, the game would be more polished. But it was still fun!

29779632.review:
This romance visual novel definitely filled me with the butterflies. It's cute rather than lustful, so if you were looking for ecchi/fanservice or softcore erotica, you won't find it here. 

To be clear, you're not actually dating cats. They're humans who received a curse that turns them into cats. 

Pros:
- Gender options
- Pronoun options (including "they"!)
- Skin tone options
- Two female romance options, four male romance options
- Decent artwork
- Interesting story, decent writing
- Good humor
- CATS!

Cons:
- Several typos, mostly punctuation errors
- The game occasionally shuts down for no reason (but thankfully, autosave helps recover what's lost)
- Finley's character is a little underdeveloped. Unlike the other characters, you don't really learn anything about her past. Her character is a little flat/one-dimensional. 

[spoiler]Personal romance preferences (ignore if you aren't a friend reading this): Graves > Hayes > Landry > Mason > Reese > Finley[/spoiler]

I read a lot of romance visual novels, and I really enjoyed this one. Definitely recommend.

I thoroughly enjoyed every single route in this game. The protagonist is uniquely representative of the modern young adult age group (or at least the nerdy subfaction that tends to like these games). The characters are quirky, endearing, and never exactly what they seem, which saves it, in my opinion, from the major downfall of most dating sims: predictability. 29548579.review:
For those who are new to Visual Novels, this will a fun little one to play for about 10-15 hours while you get used to how they work. For these people, I highly recommend Hustle Cat! (I would wait for a sale or something though.)

For those of you who have played VNs, it is still recommended, but with a few things to note before buying. 

Cons-
1.) This is a medium length VN. At the current price of $20, I'd wait for a sale.
2.) The art is very meh. I've seen worse, believe me, but when you go from Amnesia to this, it is kind of jarring.
3.) If you've played Japanese VNs, you'll know how the little pieces make them awesome (voice acting, art, story, music, ect.) This game is very American in that the pieces are nice, minus the voice acting, but never seem to go together. (sorry if that is vague)
 
Pros-
1.) The characters are really nicely done. They are a bit simple and fit a little too well in their character mold (the shy one, the goth one, the stereotype girly character, ect.) but they are easy to like. Even the side characters are well done.
2.) The secret route is great!
3.) The antagonist is pretty cool. I wish they had gone into more detail about him, but seeing as this is an otome (romances first and all) it's easy to let that slide.


Side Note- Currently, there is a bug in the gallery. Two images will be locked no matter what. They aren't romance specific images, but it still sucks. I will update if/when the bug is fixed.

1) I think all routes should be available from the get-go, even if some are harder to hunt down than others

If a sequel were to come out, I would definitely buy it and play it too. I wouldn't suggest this to a core gamer or anyone who is looking for a very verbose dating simulator, but if you feel any attraction to the initial idea this is worth picking up.
