22058398.review:
[b](A briefer summary of it all will be at the bottom, in case you don't wanna go through a full essay!)[/b]

Hustle Cat doesn't really have what you'd call a proper [i]gameplay[/i] exactly, though you could say the same about several other members of the Visual Novel genre, and I can name several that still don't give you as many options and interaction as Hustle Cat does, even if the ones it gives are a little bit light. It's definitely not for you if you're not a fan of text-heavy games, but you'll be right at home if you're into that stuff, or if you're looking to start!

With that in mind, Hustle Cat happens to have a WONDERFUL set of characters, a pretty engaging plot, and overall just really, really nice writing! The way characters are written and their dialogue is laid out is done in a way that you really don't see very often in several games, and though I absolutely liked some more than others, there truly weren't any characters I disliked at all.
Avery, the protagonist, is an easy example of splendid  characterization, and their interactions with the cafe's staff are really fun to read and enjoyable to go through.

I will say there were a couple of routes were things were handled a little bit strangely, and some certainly feel like they received less attention than others, although that tends to be mostly in the pictures department rather than in writing. General favoritism is there, but this isn't to say that the ones that were noticeably better liked by Date Nighto weren't amazing to play through!

It's easy to catch wind of how to go through each route, and though runs past your first might be a little bit uneventful on your way to taking on another one, the fact you can speed up doesn't really let that drag for too long.
[spoiler]I do wish that the whole "cat" aspect of the game, which is the lead appeal, hadn't been dropped the way it was, though, but that might just be me. I'll give them a TON of praise for using the word "witch" as unisex, though! You hardly see people realizing it's unisex in most games these days![/spoiler]

Moving on to the music, I can say it was...all right!
Nothing really stood out to me, and most of the songs began as generic before shifting to repetitive, but I wouldn't say they ever got grating or annoying to listen to, and some were very much perfect for the mood, at times.
...Big emphasis on "at times", though, as there were tons of moments through the game where I felt as though a change in song or maybe a bit of silence would've been much better suited (almost expected) for what the text was carrying the mood through. It definitely took away from some scenes, for me.

Next, we have the art! And boy, Hustle Cat is PRETTY!
The character expressions might be a little awkward rarely, but I usually found them to be really nice and fun to look at! The mugshot models themselves are really nicely shaded, with thick lines and great color choices that keep everything vibrant, cute, and just really...alive! Each character gets a very nice and decent selection of expressions as well, which keeps the text accompanying them always engaging!

If there's anything to complain about, it'd be that certain of the special event pictures tend to have awkward faces or anatomy at times, and then you have some others that just don't have shading at all, which I found really strange. These aren't so many that it'd damage the overall quality, though.

The interface is kind of generic for what you'd expect of a visual novel, and can be a little plain here and there, but it's definitely not unfitting or clashing with the style. It's cute, simple, and not pretentious or intrusive, so I can't complain at all.

One thing I absolutely wanna praise is the game's auto save feature! While it's not good advertising to say that the game crashed on me twice, it did happen at times when I was speeding through the dialogue, and my laptop happened to also be running several other things at the time.
But, thanks to the auto saving, I really didn't need to worry, since I could just hop back onto where I was just playing last time!

[h1]Overall![/h1]
Hustle Cat is adorable, and whether you're a cat person or a visual novel fan, you'll definitely like it! The cast is full of life and splendidly written dialogue, and even if the story might get a bit awkward at times, it always keeps engaging and fun to go through.

The music is a little repetitive and uninspired, and tends to clash with the mood or go on for too long sometimes, but it was never grating or annoying to listen to, at least in my opinion.

The art is gorgeous, with a few hiccups in some special scenes, but never losing charm or failing to bring life to the scene it comes along with. While the game might rely on the still character mugshots a lot, it still has a much more abundant selection of special art than most visual novels out there!

It's a pretty great game that could've been a lot better, but I can assure you it won't disappoint!

22016547.review:
I'll be honest, from reading other reviews and just watching the initial trailer video I was prepared to maybe like this game, but was more prepared to play one route and leave it in my steam library to collect dust. After just playing through one route, I can say I'm in love with it. 

Yes, these are a few tiny little issues here and there, but there is nothing that takes away from the game play or story. They seem to be things with the game engine or something along those lines? Sometimes the transitions were a bit choppy and I would occasionally get a loading screen when a new scene was loading. The actual text itself were also seem like it was sort of....lagging I guess would be the best term? For some reason it would get better when I switched from using the mouse to hitting enter and whether that was the game itself, my computer, or just a state mind is yet to be seen. Like I said though, nothing that takes away the wonderful story and art this game gives you. 

I was expecting at least one of the plot points that happened in this story, but the rest. Wow. Not even close. It never felt like it was forced to me either and I never really found myself kind of disbelieving in how the game got me there. More often then not I found myself muttering under my breath in a good surprise about things that happened. The writing is wonderful and each character shines through with their own unique qualities and characteristics. At this point I have one played through one route and I loved all the characters. What I really love though, is how Avery has a personality as well and it actually shows as you play throughout the game. Where as some VN heroines/heroes come across as completely dumb or useless, Avery never felt that way to me. 

The romance (at least the one route I played) was very natural as well. It was there, it was adorable, it made me smile and laugh, but it wasn't just in your face and then over. At this point I'm definitely looking forward to seeing how that plays out on the other routes in the game. 

If you're interested at all in the game, I would say pick it up when you have the chance. It's a lovely visual novel that definitely lands on it's feet.

21999280.review:
This dating sim was wonderful.  
The quality of the writing, artwork, and sound really shine.  
I agree with other reviews that it is very short for the price tag of $17.99 (normally $19.99).  However, I still highly recommend it.  It has instantly gone into my library of absolute favorite dating sims.

The writing is very immersing.  Going into dating sims, I expect the dialog to be really formulaic, but this one stood out.  I found myself chuckling and leaning forward in my seat with curiosity.  I especially loved the character Graves.  I was motivated to buy this just to pursue him after I saw him in the trailer (mischievous smirking, probably-a-wizard, with two different color eyes?  Yes please!).  Surprisingly, he wound up my second favorite love interest, and I really enjoyed his path!  As in, 'dead tired because I stayed up all night, [i]needing[/i] to see how his path ended' enjoyed his path.
[spoiler]And I'm still left with more questions about his past and some of Nacht's veiled comments!!!  'Think of me when  you do it again', what is he talking about?!?![/spoiler]

Which speaks to how much I loved Mason's route - my favorite of the love interests.
It had me in tears in a wonderful way.  She is a lovable character that I could not get enough of.

All of the characters are distinct and interesting.  The game does a great job of making the cafe feel like a family.  I couldn't stand Reese, but I was at least gratified that the MC constantly teases him for being a brat, and they didn't try to pass him off as anything but.

Magic, cats, coffee, and lots of fun!

If I have one gripe about the plot, it's that [spoiler] our super powers are garbage ;_;  Everyone else's are so cool!  Why was ours lame?  I kept expecting there to be a secret reason, but was disappointed that we're apparently the garbage wizard.  Also, that in many paths the explanation that we can control garbage is rushed, leaving me going, 'we can [i]what?[/i] When did that happen?'[/spoiler]

21983998.review:
When I first saw this game pop up on my recommended games list, I imagined that it was yet another one of these games that were made by an American indie company and attempting to sound Japanese. This has been a trend lately on Steam, and needless to say, a lot of them are pretty horrible.  

However, I took a leap of faith and decided to play this game, and I'm glad I did. The characters are engaging, the writing is witty and funny, and the mystery is keeping me interested. I haven't finished the game yet, but I'm really interested to see where it is going. 

The game asks for your pronouns at the beginning of the game and you are allowed to change your skin color, so it is a more inclusive game. However! This is a game that does inclusive well, without being judgy or preachy about it, which is a nice relief. It's more like the characters happen to be darker-skinned, rather than that being their entire personality and a way to get more people to play the game. 

The characters are not basic stereotypes and they react to situations in a way that is both realistic and engaging, and fitting for the setting.  I have seen no typos and the music is not irritating in the slightest. 

I think my only complaint about the game is that I would enjoy the option to make the text larger, but that's because of my own issues with vision. 

In any case, I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys visual novels.

21943914.review:
The game is exactly what one would expect from a visual novel. I bought it on a whim on a bad night and don't entirely regret it. Overall it's a recommendation for me but I do have a few things I want to say about it. Just gonna do a quick list:

Pros
- Pretty dang cute art
- Being able to choose your gender and romance whoever
- Interesting story (so far, I haven't seen all the paths)
- A pretty diverse cast of characters with interesting personalities
- INCLUDING the main character! So many of these have blank slate main characters. Avery is not that at all.
- Decent script overall, much better than I expected honestly (it's easy to cash in on the 'weird versions of sim dating' craze, what can I say xD)


Cons
- This is the most finicky skip button I have ever seen in one of these games that have a skip button! I wouldn't complain so much about this, but this game REQUIRES you to play all the routes to get the full story. Sometimes it worked fine, othertimes I would have to X out and then in for it to work. 
- Shorter run time may be a turn off at the price (my play time mostly stems from me having it on in the background and coming back to it every once in a while, someone said eight hours elsewhere and that sounds about right. I have no issue with it, but people should be aware.)
- This one is my biggest gripe: The stories really do feel imcomplete until you realize that you need to see everyone's to get a fuller picture (or at least pick the ones who actively cares more about the magic portion of the plot - Mason, my first pick, did not.) This is the first time I've ever really felt forced to romance people I had no interest in whatsoever to get any idea of the plot, because I prefer to romance female characters and this game appears to be specifically attempting to cater to the LGBTQ audience who want to follow their own preferences.
- You only have like a page of save files (I think six or eight all together?). This again is the least I have ever seen being offered, which is a bummer.

21940688.review:
I enjoyed playing this game. I'll admit that it's not the very best visual novel I've ever encountered, but I can also say that it is nowhere near the worst. 

Where to start, the art is really really great. You can pick between six different character designs. Granted, all that changes between them is the hair length and skin color, but it's still really great.

You can pick between the pronouns you want to use at the beginning, middle, or near end of the game (so pretty much any time). 

The story lines of the routes are original and fun. I can honestly say that I didn't get bored at all playing this; but I will admit that I used the "fast forward/skip" button a few times to get through the repeating dialogs towards the last couple routes. 

If you want a fun and beautiful game that has cat curses, trash magic, and mysterious co-workers; this is the game for you.

10/10 would recommend.

It is an otome, if you like otomes you will probably like this one. If you do not, then it is likely not a game meant for you. It is a more PG otome, so do not expect explicit.

The art is cute, the characters are likeable, and act III has some good intensity to it.
If you like the story and characters, it has replay value.

My only criticisms are I wish it had been a little longer to dedicate to the relationship building. As it is, it is fine, but it is not the longest game. I also wish there was some voice acting, as I feel it gives more life to the characters, but I also understand that means more time, more employees, and more money involved. My last is the antagonists’ motivation (which I will not spoil here). I feel it could have been something more substantial.

Either way, it is a fun cute story with good characters. As I said, if you like PG otomes with a bit of a weird flair to them, you will like this.

21928738.review:
[strike]First, I want to note as a caveat, I have played only two of the game's six routes thus far (with the women, cause i'm gay). Note my time played - 3.5 hours, as of when I'm writing this. Unless some of the men's routes are much longer, which I seriously doubt, I can't imagine getting more than nine hours out of this. MAYBE if you really like rereading VNs. Even then, most VN's I've got through steam are quite a bit longer.[/strike] (I've since finished all routes)

[b]I'm glad I played this game, but in good conscience I cannot recommend a game this short at this price.[/b] It is a VERY, VERY short game, and the price it's at as of my writing this review (17.99 USD) is just totally unreasonable.

[b]ETA:[/b] I've played all six routes now. Total play time 8.1 hours on record (I did kinda blitz through the mens' routes; like I said, I'm gay and biased towards the women). They were all very well written and engaging, with good art and interesting characters. I stand by everything else I've said in this review - including, unfortunately, my non-recommendation.

I can see why it's priced high; it clearly has very high quality art and text and music (particularly considering that there are six versions of Avery's face). But from a consumer standpoint it's really hard to justify.

So, on to the good.

The art is excellent, and the writing is great. Mason's route actually had me in tears. Finley is absolutely adorable. The beginning, and some short parts near the end, got a bit repetitive, but overall I liked all the different routes, how you learn different things about the characters etc.

I like the ability to choose the pronouns for Avery, your character, and also independently select your appearance (there's a more 'masculine' and a more 'feminine' face available, and you can choose between three skin tones as well). This is reflected pretty well in the gameplay as well, though there were a couple awkward moments in Finley's route where a side character's dialogue seemed to be making the assumption that Avery was male, and noone corrected him? (The pronouns still fit, it was a broader text issue. Maybe just me.)

And some small complaints, other than the length of the game. These don't affect my (non)-recommendation.

There's no text speed option that I saw, so you kind of have to click your way through each sentence of dialogue at a pretty rapid pace if you read pretty quickly. This can also lead to accidentally clicking past a certain portion of dialogue too early because you were trying to get all the sentences displayed, which leads to another quibble...

Most other VN's I've read/played, you can scroll back at least a bit to see something you might've just missed. Hustle Cat, for some reason, does not. There IS a log, so if you just missed something you can open that and see the recent text, but it's odd that you can't just scroll back a little bit. I assume this is in Ren'Py, which I KNOW can do that.

Also, this isn't something I'm actually concerned with at all, but I know some people prefer much more interactive VN's. This isn't; in all of the routes, the first third of the game is making some basic decisions about who you get close to, which determines which route you're on; the middle third is non-interactive; and the last third may have one player choice which either immediately leads to a bad end or continues the story to the end. Again, I don't mind this at all, personally; just putting it out there for people who would.

21889614.review:
[h1]Overall, Hustle Cat is a great game. There are a few niggling issues that might be easily fixed but honestly none of them are major enough to detract from what is an incredibly enjoyable game.[/h1]

Hustle Cat is one of the most enjoyable games I have played in a long time. I was immediately attracted to the project; being a cat lover and appreciating its nonbinary options (and Graves having an uncanny resemblance to my husbando) made me back the kickstarter right away.

[u]Some basic info:[/u]
[*]You can pick your pronouns (She/Her, He/Him, They/Them) and what Avery looks like (you have between masculine presenting and feminine presenting and a range of skin tones) but you cannot change the name. You can change which pronouns you want in the menu, whenever you like.
[*]You can romance any of the characters regardless of any options you pick, however one character is a secret option. 
[*]One play through lasts about 2.5 hours to 3 hours. Any subsequent ones will take less if you skip. There are 6 routes in total. There are bad ends.

[u]The good stuff:[/u]
[*]The writing is incredibly enjoyable. It's certainly on the meme-y side of things, but the jokes were great, many had me giggling out loud. A lot of scenes made me cry; but YMMV. The characters are all very likeable and have great chemistry with each other. There are so many scenes I enjoyed, and honestly it was just such a fun experience playing it. 
[*]The routes are fairly flexible. Some visual novels I have played tend to lock you in pretty early and with obvious choices, but with Hustle Cat they have a points system. Don't feel like picking one option will lock you in to that character.
[*]The art is mostly great. I really like a lot of the sprites, many of the characters have great poses and expressions that really reflect their character. Art is always important in visual novels as it tends to be what people judge the game on, and I think for the most part Hustle Cat does a great job.
[*]The characters are all great. I was immediately draw to Graves, but then began to love Finley and Mason too. And then Hayes, Landry and Reese… Unlocking the secret route involves putting time in with everyone, but I don't believe any one of these characters routes was anything less than enjoyable.
[*]This is an incredibly inclusive game! The fact that you can choose your pronouns and date anyone regardless of gender is incredibly amazing and honestly something that just cannot be faulted, unless you are against anything vaguely 'SJW-like'. The inclusivity is not harming you in any way and you don't have to romance anyone you don't want to; if the games inclusivity bothers you in any way then this just isn't the game for you.

[u]A few issues:[/u]
[*]The screenshot button and steam overlay do not work. The game is easily tabbed out of, but I found the fact I couldn't take screenshots with steam really quite disappointed. I wanted to share things with friends who had already played the game and had to use a different piece of software to do so.
[*]This is more or less severe depending on taste, but while I thought the majority of the sprites were good, some of the CG were disappointing. In particular I think of Mason's end CG, which seems to be unshaded and just looks a lot worse compared to the other CG. It almost seems like it was a time issue; the CG simply looks a little unfinished.
[*]The skip button is okay, but could be better. The transitions still take a while and so spamming space bar is often a bit quicker. 
[*]The story feels a little disjointed in some places, and the pacing is rather quick. At one point Avery started talking about their crush; I had no idea who it was and how it happened! I know that it was because of a choice I made, but it doesn't make much sense if you play it without realizing that you effectively skipped a scene. I suppose this gave some suspense as to who I was actually romancing… I would've liked it to have been longer so I could spend more time with the characters, but of course I would have expected the price to be more too. In my opinion, this game is good value for money at full price.
[*]There are so few save files! Having played a fair amount of visual novels I am used to having pages and pages of save files, but I found Hustle Cat a bit lacking.


I enjoyed Hustle Cat immensely and am so glad I backed it on kickstarter. Whether you're interested in the plot, the cats, the characters, the inclusivity, or something else, you will find this game enjoyable. Visual novel purists might be turned off by the game's elements that are atypical of the genre, but I believe anyone interested in the premise or any of the game's aspect will find it enjoyable. If in doubt, wait for steam sale, but if you're in any way excited by the game, buy it now. Thanks Date Nighto, I won't be forgetting Hustle Cat for a long time.

40408316.review:
This is a stunningly fun, well-written game that unexpectedly tugged at my heart-strings. The protagonist is a solid character, with great internal dialogue that fits for either a male or female character. The gender flexibility allows for personalized character design, even going so far as to offer a singular 'they/them' pronoun along with 'he/him' and 'she/her'. Whatever choice you make, your character will be treated - and loved - equally by any of the characters. 

The most intersting thing about the game is the overarching narrative that takes place with each romance option you play through. While the first five romances follow similar formats, each one will give you just a bit more information on the plot than you had before. And once you've worked through all five, you unlock the - in my personal opinion - best romance. this last story is wonderfully done, weaving together everything you learned from previous playthroughs, while giving you fresh insight and closure on the issue. Also, it's heart-melting. Not everyone will feel the same way about it, of course, but if you like romance with a bit more focus on the actual people involved, this is a great choice.

Hustle Cat - довольно забавная и очень милая новелла. У нее очень приятная рисовка, цветовая гамма, много котиков, неплохие шутки местами. 

 А вот сюжет - ну такое. Он интересен в первое прохождение. Интересно во второе - хотя стойте, он такой же? Может, просто именно у этих персонажей похожие руты? Окей, начнем третий... нет, всё также. Все руты в этой игре развиваются по одной схеме, и к концу прохождения это раздражает. Ещё больше раздражает отсутствие возможности скипать только уже прочитанный текст, останавливаясь на новом. Вместе эти два минуса становятся большой проблемой, прохождение отнимает в два раза больше времени, чем могло бы. 

 Однако не смотря на одинаковый сценарий рутов, все персонажи, их характеры, внешность и предыстории - очень сильно отличаются друг от друга. О героях интересно что-то узнавать, у них красивые арты, много захватывающих моментов, и за это я горячо рекомендую эту игру. Тут правда во многих можно безвозвратно влюбиться <3

 Вердикт - очень милая новелла, чтобы занять 18 часов своей жизни когда тебе грустненько, одиноко и хочется попрактиковать чтение на английском - он в игре довольно сложный
 
 Семь готических котиков из десяти

39921567.review:
A sweet, lovely game with routes that are all worth playing. Each builds well on the others to reveal thoughtful worldbuilding (which reminded me a little of YA novels like the Circle of Magic or Diane Duane's Wizardry series--though not as dark as the latter!) and unique plots for each character, with a final special route pulling most of the secrets together. Especially good if you're queer, because you can set the main character to be male, female, or nonbinary, and can date all of the characters regardless of your choices. Also--cats? People turning into cats and vice-versa? How is this not a good thing?

PROS:
- Can play as nonbinary, male, or female and still date all the characters
- Very cute art
- A nice range of character types, so you'll like find at least one character you really enjoy
- Each route has lots of unique content and adds to both your understanding of the world and the story (all routes are worth playing)
- Fast-forward feature
- Save anywhere feature
- Cats!

CONS:
- I was little eh about the music
- Not as many women to date as men
- Very few choices; you make about three and that seals your route. Don't go into this one expecting a game--it's definitely more a set of linked stories
- Main character has a distinct personality, which you may or may not like
- Some of the characters' plots left me feeling like they were more friends the romance game constraints forced me to kiss than actually people my character was romantically into.
- You'll have mixed feelings about the secret plot if May-December romances in fiction make you go "nope!"

39833600.review: Completely unplayable on Windows 10.  My playtime is inaccurate: I only got to actually play for a few minutes, because this game constantly hangs, then keeps running in the background and will not close no matter what. Incompatible with Steam Overlay, causes Windows itself to entirely lock up.  Crashes mid-game, just opening the game and trying to load save files causes crashes.  Currently just opening the game causes all of Windows to hang and lock up so badly that I can't even restart the OS and have had to hard reboot my computer several times.  No combination of compatibility modes, turning off the Steam overlay, etc. has helped.  I'm on a fully updated gaming PC, so this is definitely not a problem of inadequate specs.  These devs should frankly be ashamed of themselves.  If they couldn't program a proprietary game framework that's not a complete travesty, they should've just used RenPy like basically every other English visual novel developer.

39801215.review:
I really wanted to like this game. I really did. I'm a big otome fan and any effort made to introduce the genre to Western players gets a thumbs-up from me.

But this isn't a true otome, or a well done dating sim on that matter. The story has holes everywhere in it, the art is inconsistent and at some points it even looks unfinished and the engine crashes too many times to count while also being the program that uses the most CPU of my computer when I played it.

Don't waste your money. Support other games. This is a lazy effort by a company that only tries to cash in on a trend while also pandering to fujoshis.

39668454.review:
The game has quite a few things going for it: cute story, great anime style graphics, and comedy.

I can't recommend the game though because it is just another linear, non-interactive visual novel.

There are so many things that they could have added in to make the game fun!  Don't read any futher unless you don't mind spoilers:

They could have made it so that the spell learning process was affected by user choice.

During battle, the user could have different ways of winning based on the spells learned and whoever their relationship partner was.

The Jelly Donut social media project could have been a mini-game in itself!  Arrange the photos, choose outfits, backdrops and tricks to perform, etc.  So much potential there!

The villain of the story was....uninteresting.  The conflict was not developed enough to make me feel any emotion other than annoyance at the fact that I didn't understand his motivation.

This studio shows promise and I hope that they break out of this boring visual novel mold and bring on the interaction in their next game.
